metadata.case_name: Sri Vinayagar Transports v. Southern Roadways Private Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant is proprietor of Sri Vinayagar Transports, Woriyur, Tiruchirapalli, holding permit to ply bus on route Tiruchirapalli Mainguard Gate to Tiruchirapalli Railway Station via Palakarai and Round Tana.

Appellant applied on July 19, 1954, to Regional Transport Officer, Tiruchirapalli, for variation of route to ply between Mainguard Gate and Golden Rock via Palakarai, Round Tana, Railway Station, retrace to Round Tana and thence to Golden Rock.
Regional Transport Officer notified application, called for objections, heard application and objections on July 15, 1955, rejected the application.
Appellant filed Revision Petition before Government of Madras under s.64A of Motor Vehicles Act.
Madras Government heard objections, by order dated December 28, 1955, set aside RTO order and directed grant of variation as prayed.
Respondent Southern Roadways Private Ltd. filed petition under Art. 226 Constitution on January 2, 1956, for writ of certiorari to quash Madras Government order.
In writ petition before Rajagopalan J., respondent raised plea (not in original petition) that RTO had no jurisdiction to grant variation, following Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 107 of 1955.
Rajagopalan J. held RTO no jurisdiction, consequently Government no jurisdiction in revision, set aside Government order dated Dec 28, 1955, without deciding other contentions.

Appellant appealed to Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 110 of 1956, correctness of Writ Appeal 107/1955 questioned but not pressed due to Full Bench decision in Writ Appeals 56 & 57/1956 on April 12, 1957.
Division Bench rejected appellant's contentions on submission to jurisdiction and Government's power under s.64A, affirmed single judge, granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Government of Madras Notification No. G.O. MS. 527 dated February 14, 1953, authorized Regional Transport Officers to exercise powers of State Transport Authority under ss.48A,51A,56A.
Further notification October 20, 1955, reorganizing department, but 1953 notification in force at time of application.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Regional Transport Officer had power to vary the conditions of a permit to ply a stage carriage under s.44A of the Motor Vehicles Act.
Whether respondent submitted to jurisdiction of RTO and could not later challenge via certiorari.
Whether Government under s.64A could grant variation in revision even if RTO lacked jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents submitted to jurisdiction of Regional Transport Officer and therefore could not at later stage obtain discretionary writ of certiorari on ground of lack of jurisdiction.
Even if RTO had no jurisdiction, Government order under s.64A could not be said to be without jurisdiction as Government had power to pass such orders on revision.

Regional Transport Officer is subordinate to State Transport Commissioner under s.44A, wide words include administrative subordination, no need for rules under s.133A(3). Notification G.O. MS 527/1953 validly conferred power.

respondent_arguments.text: Regional Transport Officer had no jurisdiction to deal with application for variation of conditions of permit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.48A Motor Vehicles Act; Writ Appeal No.107/1955; Full Bench T. Krishnaswamy Mudaliar v. P.S. Palani Pillai

respondent_arguments.text: Government had no jurisdiction in revision under s.64A to grant what RTO could not.

'Any officer subordinate to him' in s.44A means statutory/functional subordination per rules under s.133A(3); no rules framed, RTO not subordinate to Commissioner; administrative subordination insufficient.

court_reasoning.text: High Court rightly allowed respondent to urge lack of RTO jurisdiction despite not in original writ petition, as point arose post Division Bench decision in Writ Appeal 107/1955; goes to root of jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court could not refuse reliance on its own binding decision.

court_reasoning.text: s.64A is revisional power; Government cannot pass order in revision which subordinate authority lacked jurisdiction to pass; cannot exercise original jurisdiction vested elsewhere; no specific power in s.43 or s.48A for Government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'as it thinks fit' in s.64A limited to ambit of Act.

court_reasoning.text: s.44A authorizes State Government, notwithstanding anything in Act, to notify State Transport Commissioner or subordinate officer to exercise powers in lieu of other authorities like State Transport Authority under s.48A; 'any officer subordinate to him' includes administratively subordinate RTO per departmental lists, notifications; no rules under s.133A(3) framed, so no conflict; wide interpretation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: RTO subordinate to Commissioner; Notification G.O. MS 527/1953 validly conferred power on RTO.

holdings.text: Regional Transport Officer had jurisdiction to vary conditions of permit by virtue of power conferred by Notification No. G.O. MS. 527 under s.44A; consequently Government had power under s.64A to direct variation on revision.
Respondent could challenge jurisdiction despite prior submission and omission in writ petition.
Government's revisional power under s.64A does not extend to granting relief subordinate lacked jurisdiction for.

precedents_cited.case_name: T. Krishnaswamy Mudaliar v. P.S. Palani Pillai
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench Madras HC held 'subordinate' in s.44A means statutory subordination via rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. Veeraswamy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench AP HC held RTO subordinate to Transport Commissioner under s.44A, word 'any' gives wide generality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Writ Appeal No. 107 of 1955 (Madras HC Division Bench)
precedents_cited.relevance: Held RTO no jurisdiction to vary permit conditions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Writ Appeals Nos. 56 and 57 of 1956 (Madras HC Full Bench)

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions on permits, authorities, variation of conditions, revision; s.44A key for delegation to RTO; s.64A revisional powers limited.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition for certiorari to quash government order.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed by majority (Imam J for bench, Subba Rao J dissenting); High Court judgments set aside; case remanded to single Judge of Madras High Court for rehearing writ petition on other undecided contentions.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand for rehearing; appellant entitled to costs in Supreme Court, costs in High Court abide result.
outcome.costs: Costs to appellant in this Court; costs in High Court abide the result.

key_quotes.text: 'any officer subordinate to him' ... are wide enough ... and incapable of being given the restricted meaning suggested ... Regional Transport Officers are officers subordinate to the Transport Commissioner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of s.44A allowing delegation to RTO.

key_quotes.text: s.64A is a power ... by way of revision ... [Government] could not substitute ... its own order directing the variation ... which the authority ... had no jurisdiction to pass.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of revisional jurisdiction under s.64A.
